question: Posted By CCF Neurology MD - AY on September 16, 1998 at 21:02:16:In Reply to: Chronic Foot burning and pain posted by Karen on September 16, 1998 at 20:37:23:After many tests, including 2 EMG tests, blood work, a test for diabetes, back exrays and physical examinations, my feet, burning and paining, have not been diagnosed and steadily detereorating.  Noone can say what it is except that it is neuralgia.  I am not convinced of this.  Could it be arthritis?  Not much shows up on the exrays.  Could the diabetes test not be thorough enough?  It mimics peripheral neuropathy.  What are my options?Thanks for your question.  The burning pain described in your message ismost commonly associated with peripheral neuropathy, and diabetes mellitusis the general systemic disorder most commonly associated with peripheralneuropathy.  However, it would quite unusual for peripheral neuropathy tobe the initial presentation of diabetes, without the other more commonsymptoms, such as polydipsia (constant thirst), polyuria (frequent urination),etc.It is possible to have a peripheral neuropathy and not be detected by EMG,because the EMG test cannot evaluate the very small unmyelinated nerve fibersthat transmit the pain information.If all your results are negative, you might discuss with your doctor atrial of medications usually used for such neuropathic pain such asNeurontin or Tegretol.I hope this information is helpful.  Best of luck.This information is provided for general medical education purposes only.Please consult your doctor regarding diagnostic and treatment options.
